title: 114_hr6510
content: The "Save the Children Act of 2016" is the short title of this Act. Congress expresses its sense through this Act. Congress acknowledges the humanitarian crisis faced by Syrian children due to civil war violence and displacement to refugee camps. Efforts should be made to relocate and care for up to 25,000 young Syrian minor children refugees. The Act aims to provide immediate care for up to 25,000 young Syrian minor children refugees in the United States over three years. Efforts should be made to reunite or relocate these children back to Syria once the civil war violence decreases. The Save the Children Program aims to provide care for young Syrian minor children refugees in the United States with efforts to reunite or relocate them back to Syria once the civil war violence decreases. The Save the Children Program grants visas for young Syrian children aged three to ten to enter the US until civil war violence decreases. After a designated time by the Department of State, there is a six-month grace period for guardians to be identified before visas expire. The Save the Children Program grants visas for young Syrian children aged three to ten to enter the US until civil war violence decreases. Qualifying children must have guardians present to relinquish custody or be orphaned to be eligible for the visa. The Office of Refugee Resettlement establishes a Coordinator for the program who reports to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Coordinator for the Save the Children Program, appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, can hire additional personnel with approval from the Office of Personnel Management. Federal departments can provide personnel on a reimbursable or nonreimbursable basis as requested. The Coordinator for the Save the Children Program, appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, can hire additional personnel from federal departments to assist in carrying out duties. The Coordinator is responsible for identifying qualifying minor children for the Program and implementing their temporary resettlement in the United States. The Coordinator for the Save the Children Program, appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, is responsible for identifying orphaned eligible children and implementing their temporary resettlement in the United States. They cooperate with approved organizations and government authorities to assist those admitted under the Program, in line with relevant laws, international agreements, and the interests of the United States. The Coordinator consults with key officials to ensure Program operations align with laws, international agreements, and US interests, aiming for family reunification within six months post-civil war violence reduction in Syria. The Program will terminate six months after certification of a sustained reduction in civil war violence and newly displaced Syria inhabitants. The Office will consult with relevant departments for further actions. The Office, in consultation with relevant departments, will make efforts to reunite minor children admitted to the United States with their parents or caretakers as required by international agreements and US laws. The Program may be suspended or terminated if deemed necessary for US foreign policy and domestic security interests. Appropriations will be made as necessary for the Program's purposes. The Coordinator will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment detailing the Program's implementation. Appropriations are authorized for each fiscal year to carry out the purposes of this section. The Office can use funds from the Migration and Refugee Assistance Act for this purpose upon the President's designation. SEC. 4. TEMPORARY NONIMMIGRANT VISA. The Program shall admit alien minor children aged three to ten under a temporary nonimmigrant visa, with a preference for those already in custody outside Syria. The number of children admitted will increase over three program years, contingent on reduced violence in Syria. The Syrian Civil War Minor Child Protection Act of 2016 allows for the admission of alien minor children aged three to ten from Syria or born in Syria but currently displaced, under a temporary nonimmigrant visa, contingent on reduced violence in Syria. The Secretary of State, in consultation with other officials, has established policies for aliens to temporarily reside in the United States under the Save the Children Program. Aliens admitted under this program can stay in the US until civil war violence in Syria significantly decreases, as certified by the Secretary of State. The Department of State has implemented policies for aliens to temporarily stay in the US under the Save the Children Program until civil war violence in Syria significantly decreases. There is a substantial reduction in the numbers of newly displaced Syrian inhabitants, with a six month grace period for reunification efforts.
